entry.name: load
entry.title: .load()
entry.desc: Bind an event handler to the "load" JavaScript event.

argument.name: handler
argument.desc: A function to execute when the event is triggered.

argument.name: eventData
argument.desc: An object containing data that will be passed to the event handler.

argument.name: handler
argument.desc: A function to execute each time the event is triggered.

longdesc.p: This method is a shortcut for .on( "load", handler ).

The load event is sent to an element when it and all sub-elements have been completely loaded. This event can be sent to any element associated with a URL: images, scripts, frames, iframes, and the window object.

As soon as the iframe has been loaded, the handler is called.

div.p: The Ajax module also has a method named .load(). Which one is fired depends on the set of arguments passed.

p.b: Caveats of the load event when used with images
p.p: A common challenge developers attempt to solve using the .load() shortcut is to execute a function when an image (or collection of images) have completely loaded. There are several known caveats with this that should be noted. These are:

ul.li: It doesn't work consistently nor reliably cross-browser
It doesn't fire correctly in WebKit if the image src is set to the same src as before
It doesn't correctly bubble up the DOM tree
Can cease to fire for images that already live in the browser's cache

div.p: Note: The .live() and .delegate() methods cannot be used to detect the load event of an iframe. The load event does not correctly bubble up the parent document and the event.target isn't set by Firefox, IE9 or Chrome, which is required to do event delegation.

example.desc: Run a function when the page is fully loaded including graphics and other resources.
Add the class bigImg to each image with height greater than 100 on load, implementing a partial workaround for image-loading issues.
